entries.description: These drums are sampled in The Pharcyde’s, “Passin me By,” but the entirety of this track stands strong on its own. I want those horn hits to punctuate my life. The identity of the Skull Snaps was largely unknown for a few decades.
I love discovering that groups are from Chicago when I never knew they were from Chicago. You may recognize this from Big Daddy Kane’s, “Ain’t No Half-Steppin’”
Marlena is confidently restrained in this cover of “California Soul,” backed by the production value of a massive pop hit. This is a great talent doing her job damn well.
This Blue Note recording was one of the first Jazz records I listened to as a young adult. The patience of this track is something I come back to when I need to slow down.
The sampling of William Bell’s, “I Forgot to be Your Lover” is perfectly executed here by The Alchemist.

entries.track: I Forgot To Be Your Lover
entries.description: This is such a beautiful song from Stax’s William Bell. It is sampled in Dilated Peoples’ “Worst comes to Worst.”

entries.album: Don Letts Presents the Mighty Trojan Sound
entries.description: Producer Lloyd “Spiderman” Campbell and singer Claudette are both tucked away beneath relative obscurity. This track is one of my favorites.
Drexel University, Vinyl Me, Please, and Reservoir Media are joint-releasing this full-length for the first time in history. This is my favorite track on the record so far.

This track contains one of the most sampled drum tracks in the history of hip hop. The high school band, “The Honey Drippers” were discovered by singer Roy C. This dense anti-Nixon funk has been a reminder to me of how little has changed since 1973.

entries.album: Ritratto di Mina: I singoli, Vol. 2
entries.description: Originally recorded for the 1963 album, “Stessa Spiaggia Stesso Mare,” this track showcases the vocal talent of Italy’s prolific Mina. She was banned from TV and radio in 1963. If you’re wondering how that turned out, she now has over 70 studio recordings, as recent as 2018.

La Femme makes this Chuck Berry cover their own. This album from 2013 was a gift from a dear friend and is one of the more exciting recordings I listen to with consistency. Fair warning, this bonus track is not on vinyl, but the LP is more than worth it.

entries.album: Been in the Storm So Long - Spirituals & Shouts, Children's Game Songs, and Folktales
entries.track: Jesus Knows All About My Troubles
entries.description: I have no qualms posting this album for a second time. After letting this recording hit you, you’ll see why.

entries.album: The Skeletal Essences of Afro Funk, Vol. 3: 1969-1980
entries.description: Beninese Orchestre Poly Rythmo de Cotonou is also referred to as “Tout Puissant,” or “All Mighty.” This track’s title translates to, “Who knows the future?” “When you come in the world and you have money / It’s not a reason to be proud.”
Eddie Bo is known for the style he brought to the piano, and this funky track features none of it. No New Orleans artist has released as many singles as Eddie other than Fats Domino.

Danyél Waro was born in Réunion, the source of Maloya — a rhythmic style of music established by African and Malagasy slaves on the island. In the early 70’s it was considered a threat to the French imperialist state and subsequently banned. Waro, who is still active today, has been recognized by many indigenous groups for his work reviving the traditions of Réunion.

Rachel Sweet made this record when she was 16. She won an electric garage door opener for her singing at the age of three. This album oscillates between karaoke-production Country, Punk, a Carla Thomas cover, and the straight coolness this track.

entries.album: Have You Been Good to Yourself
entries.track: Have You Been Good to Yourself
entries.description: Home-recorded straight to cassette, this track along with six others were recorded by Johnnie Frierson before he was shipped off to fight in Vietnam. He is the brother of singer Wendy Rene. This album is worth an intentional listen.
Memphis’ Mary Frierson was given the stage name “Wendy Rene” by Otis Redding. She co-wrote this song with her brother Johnnie. “I’ll try to hard my sorrow / I wonder can I hold them til tomorrow.”

The first time I heard this track was on a library-rented CD in 2004. Charles was speaking of things that in my context, I could only hope to understand. 15-odd years later, this piece reminds me that I will never be able to fully understand the experience of a black person in America.
I have no idea what this song is about, but this is another awesome track from 60’s Benin.

My high school contemplation was often set to the tune of Mehldau’s Largo and Elegiac Cycle. This more recent collaboration with drummer Mark Guiliana is markedly more experimental and is precisely the music I was dying to experience back then. Check out the live performance of this track.
This Beninese artist recorded throughout the 60’s and 70’s. Daptone released this compilation in 2011.

entries.album: Saigon Rock & Soul: Vietnamese Classic Tracks 1968-1974
entries.track: Nỗi Buồn Con Gái (The Sadness Of Being A Girl)
entries.description: Carol Kim is regarded as South Vietnam's Queen of Soul. “When we are separated / Our love is full of tears / How long is our youth? / Being a girl is so difficult / Beauty is like smoke and cloud / It will fade to nothingness”

The story of Jackson C. Frank is tragic. His first and only release was recorded with the help of Paul Simon in 1965. This track is from the “Kitchen Tapes” — demos which he recorded in 1997. He died the day after his 56th birthday in 1999.
Sampled in Dilla’s “Fuck the Police.” So happy to have found this record. René is a Belgian composer and violinist and this compilation is a sample gold mine.
This is not Yoko’s “Plastic Ono Band.” You can tell the difference by who is laying on who on the cover...and by whether or not you’re able to listen to it more than once in a 24 hour period.

If your loved one leaves you before going to an Aretha Franklin show and you find yourself hoping Aretha plays a set that will convince them to get back with you, you will definitely be consoled by this George Jackson track.

entries.artist: Philip Glass, Kronos Quartet, Michael Riesman
entries.track: KYOKO'S HOUSE ("stage blood is not enough")
entries.description: Clean uneffected electric guitar sporadically appears on this Philip Glass soundtrack. It adds a raw and unpolished layer to this working picture I have of Glass.
“Don’t huzzle for love, cause it’s gonna come to you.” A gem from Eastern Nigeria’s Apostles.
This 2016 release reignited my inner 2006. New release coming next month.
I sit cross-legged when Serengeti tells stories. He is worth your attention. The letters defined in this song spell FUBU (×4), FILA, BOSS, PACO, JNCO, and USED.
The name, “Niney” refers to the thumb Winston Holness lost in an accident. Niney is one of Jamaica’s most revered producers. “Blood and Fire” was his first hit.
The story of Yup Juns was limited to three years due to the arrest of Shin Joong Hyun by South Korea’s authoritarian regime shortly after the release of their second record in 1975.

entries.album: Negro Prison Songs from the Mississippi State Penitentiary
entries.description: Led by a prisoner named, “22” this work song ends with an observation of the prison industrial complex. “Police get you and you workhouse bound.” Thank Alan Lomax for this 1958 recording.

I cannot put into words how much this performance affects me. I found it yesterday and wish I found it a long time ago. I have cried during every listen of this track. Stop whatever you are doing and give this your time. There is video of this historic album’s recording and its documentary form will be in theaters soon.
The New Orleans strut of this track begs you to move your body and you should oblige it. The Meters are considered by many as originators of funk.

entries.track: Something’s Got A Hold On Me
entries.description: Etta’s rawness is unmistakable. She has such a commanding presence that it is easy to overlook the entire choir on this track.

entries.track: How Long Do I Have To Wait For You?
entries.description: This introduction may be redundant, but it’s worth the risk. Sharon Jones released her first record at 40. Daptone’s first release was a Sharon Jones record. This track is one of the catchiest I have ever heard.

Charles Mingus was my entry point into jazz as an angsty teenage bassist. This composition is an elegy for saxophonist Lester Young. My initial exposure was to this later recording from 1963. The original is titled, “Goodbye Pork Pie Hat” on 1959’s, “Mingus Ah Um.”

entries.album: Sam Cooke With The Soul Stirrers
entries.track: Nearer To Thee - Live at the Shrine
entries.description: This live performance (The Great 1955 Shrine Concert) features an utterly untethered Sam Cooke and Paul Foster. The climax of this performance is hair-raising-ly palpable. It decidedly steps miles over the fine line Gospel music was walking at the time.
